sentences.sentence: And so the King’s daughter washed heavy pots( 罐 ) in a dark room deep inside the castle( 城堡 ), from before it was light till far into the night, so that she never saw the sun.
At first she was afraid that someone from the court might see her, but she hardly ever even saw the other servants.
Her only friends( 朋友 ) were the pots she washed, whom she got to know so well, that she recognized( 认识 ) every scratch( 刮痕 ) and dent( 凹陷 ) on them.
Slowly she forgot that she had ever been a proud princess( 公主 ) who sat on a high throne( 王座 ) and got her pleasure from laughing at kings.
And as she slowly forgot her past, she slowly became—not happy, exactly, but at peace with herself and what her life had become.
She would scrape( 刮掉 ) the leftover( 剩下的 ) food out of the pots, and then hide inside her clothes and take them home for her and her husband to eat.
One day the King’s eldest son was getting married,
and the poor woman went upstairs( 上台阶 ), and peeked( 偷看 ) past the edge of the door to the Great Hall to see what was going on.
And the palace was lighted up, and the guests arrived, each person handsomer( 更英俊的 ) than the one before, and all was brilliant( 亮丽的 ) and shining and beautiful.
She thought of her own fate( 命运 ) with a sad heart, and regretted her former pride and contempt( 轻视 ) which had brought her so low.
And as the rich and delicious dishes that smelled so good were carried in and out,
the servants would give her a little, which she put into the pots that she hid inside her clothes, planning to take it home.
And then a very handsome and important man came in, clothed in silk and velvet( 天鹅绒 ), with a gold chain( 项链 ) round his neck.
And when he saw the beautiful woman hiding behind the door, he took her hand and asked her to dance with him.
But she refused, all trembling( 颤抖 ), for she saw it was King Thrushbeard, who had come to ask her to marry him, and whom she had turned away with contemptuous( 轻蔑的 ) laughter.
It was no use for her to resist( 反抗 )—he led her into the room.
And all at once the hidden pots in which she had put the food slipped( 滑落 ) down and broke open,
and the pieces of meat and bread and the soup were splattered( 散落 ) all over the floor.
And when the people saw that, everyone pointed and laughed at her.
She felt so ashamed( 羞愧的 ) that she wished herself ten miles underground.
She rushed to the door to escape( 逃离 ), when a man caught her just on the steps.
She turned to look at him, and it was King Thrushbeard.
He said to her in a kind voice,
“Do not be afraid. I and the beggar( 乞丐 ) with whom you lived in the wretched( 讨厌的 ) little hut( 茅舍 ) are the same person.
For love of you I disguised( 乔装打扮 ) myself, and it was I who broke your pots, disguised as a soldier( 士兵 ) on a horse.
I did these things to bring down your proud heart, and to humble( （使）感到自惭 ) your pride, which caused you to laugh at me.”
Then she cried bitterly( 伤心地 ), and said,
“I have done great wrong, and am not worthy to be your wife.”
But he said,
“Take courage, the evil( 倒霉的 ) days are gone over. Now, let us celebrate our wedding( 婚礼 ) day.”
Then the ladies-in-waiting came and put on her splendid( 华丽的 ) clothing; and her father came, and the whole court, and wished her joy( 幸福 ) on her marriage with King Thrushbeard.
And then the wonderful celebration began.
I cannot help wishing that you and I could have been there too.

options.en: She slowly became at peace with herself and what her life had become.
